title: One-Stage Laparoscopic Pelvic Lymphadenectomy and Radical Perineal Prostatectomy
abstract: No AccessJournal of Urology1 Oct 1994One-Stage Laparoscopic Pelvic Lymphadenectomy and Radical Perineal Prostatectomy Raju Thomas, Richard Steele, Rodney Smith, and William Brannan Raju ThomasRaju Thomas More articles by this author , Richard SteeleRichard Steele More articles by this author , Rodney SmithRodney Smith More articles by this author , and William BrannanWilliam Brannan More articles by this author View All Author Informationhttps://doi.org/10.1016/S0022-5347(17)32531-4AboutPDF ToolsAdd to favoritesDownload CitationsTrack CitationsPermissionsReprints ShareFacebookLinked InTwitterEmail Laparoscopic pelvic lymph node dissection is currently an accepted procedure for staging adenocarcinoma of the prostate. To assess the feasibility and efficacy of performing laparoscopic pelvic lymph node dissection and radical perineal prostatectomy during the same anesthesia, we retrospectively analyzed 98 patients with clinically localized adenocarcinoma of the prostate who were candidates for radical prostatectomy. Of the patients 12 (12%) underwent laparoscopic pelvic lymph node dissection only since they had metastatic disease to the pelvic lymph nodes on frozen section evaluation (the Gleason pathological grade was 2 to 4 in 2 patients, 5 to 7 in 8 and 8 in 2). Of the remaining 86 patients who underwent radical perineal prostatectomy for definitive management 76 (88%) underwent 1-stage radical perineal prostatectomy immediately after laparoscopic pelvic lymph node dissection, while 10 (12%) in the initial stages of our series underwent delayed perineal prostatectomy following laparoscopic pelvic lymph node dissection (2-stage). The average postoperative hospital stay in the 1-stage group was 3.11 days, yet 19 (25%) patients were discharged from the hospital within 48hours and another 39 (51%) within 72hours. Thus, 76% of the patients were discharged from the hospital within 72hours of laparoscopic pelvic lymph node dissection and radical perineal prostatectomy. The advent of laparoscopic pelvic lymph node dissection and radical perineal prostatectomy has found a resurgence at our institutions, with its lower morbidity rate and more rapid return to normal activity for these patients. Based on our results, we recommend laparoscopic pelvic lymph node dissection followed by radical perineal prostatectomy as a 1-stage treatment option for localized adenocarcinoma of the prostate. © 1994 by The American Urological Association Education and Research, Inc.FiguresReferencesRelatedDetailsCited bySAITO S and MURAKAMI G (2018) Radical Perineal Prostatectomy: A Novel Approach For Lymphadenectomy from Perineal IncisionJournal of Urology, VOL. 170, NO. 4 Part 1, (1298-1300), Online publication date: 1-Oct-2003.RUIZ-DEYA G, DAVIS R, SRIVASTAV S, WISE A and THOMAS R (2018) OUTPATIENT RADICAL PROSTATECTOMY: IMPACT OF STANDARD PERINEAL APPROACH ON PATIENT OUTCOMEJournal of Urology, VOL. 166, NO. 2, (581-586), Online publication date: 1-Aug-2001.Stone N, Stock R and Unger P (2018) LAPAROSCOPIC PELVIC LYMPH NODE DISSECTION FOR PROSTATE CANCER: COMPARISON OF THE EXTENDED AND MODIFIED TECHNIQUESJournal of Urology, VOL. 158, NO. 5, (1891-1894), Online publication date: 1-Nov-1997.Weldon V, Tavel F and Neuwirth H (2018) CONTINENCE, POTENCY AND MORBIDITY AFTER RADICAL PERINEAL PROSTATECTOMYJournal of Urology, VOL. 158, NO. 4, (1470-1475), Online publication date: 1-Oct-1997.Thomas R, Steele R and Ahuja S (2018) Complications of Urological Laparoscopy: A Standardized 1 Institution ExperienceJournal of Urology, VOL. 156, NO. 2, (469-471), Online publication date: 1-Aug-1996.Parra R, Isorna S, Garcia Perez M, Cummings J and Boullier J (2018) Radical Perineal Prostatectomy without Pelvic Lymphadenectomy: Selection Criteria and Early ResultsJournal of Urology, VOL. 155, NO. 2, (612-615), Online publication date: 1-Feb-1996.Thomas R (2018) Editorial: The Evolving World of Urological LaparoscopyJournal of Urology, VOL. 154, NO. 2, (487-488), Online publication date: 1-Aug-1995.
